StringWithMarkup.String: In meat the amount of benzo(e)pyrene present depends on the method of cooking: time of exposure, distance of the heat source and whether or not the melted fat is allowed to drip into the heat source. Charcoal broiled or barbecued meat contained 1.7 to 7.5 ug/kg; up to 17.5 ug/kg were found in charcoal broiled T bone steak. In smoked ham, up to 5.2 ug/kg benzo(e)pyrene were found; heavy smoking increased the content to 17.9 ug/kg. Benzo(e)pyrene was detected in tomatoes at a concentration of 0.2 ug/kg. 1 out of 15 brands of whisky contained benzo(e)pyrene at a concentration of 0.3 ug/L; black tea extract contained 1.9 to 22.3 ug/kg benzo(e)pyrene; baker's dry yeast contained 3.1 to 55 ug/kg; roasted peanuts contained up to 0.4 ug/kg benzo(e)pyrene; and roasted coffee contained 0.3 to 7.2 ug/kg benzo(e)pyrene. The compound has laso been detected not qunatified in salad, tomatoes, spinach, kale, cereals, vegetables, roasted coffee, black tea, roasted peanuts and yeast(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: The following benzo(e)pyrene concentrations have been reported for various foods, ug/kg: smoked herring and salmon, 0.4 to 1.2; barbecued beef, 1.7; canned smoked oysters, 16.0; canned non smoked oysters, 1.0; smoked sausage, hams, pork and bacon, 0.2 to 2.0; charbroiled steak, chicken, hamburger and frankfurters, 2.0 to 20; vegetable oils, 0.4 to 2.6; spinach, 6.9; salads, 3.7 to 14.7; kale, 1.1 to 76.2; soybeans, 4.3; cereals, 0.3 to 4.9; various char broiled steaks and ribs, 5.5 to 7.5(1). Based upon a total diet study conducted in the United Kingdom, the contribution of benzo(e)pyrene from individual food groups to the total dietary load are as follows: cereals, 31%; meat, 3%; fish, 1%; oils/fats, 53%; fruit/sugar, 3%; vegetables, 9%; and beverages and milk, 0%(2); benzo(e)pyrene concentrations in the individual food groups were as follows, ug/kg: cereals, 0.17 to 0.29 (0.22 average); meat, <0.08 to 0.13 (0.03 average); fish, 0.09 to 0.34 (0.12 average); oils/fats, <0.08 to 3.20 (1.10 average); fruits and sugars, <0.08 to 0.08 (0.03 average); root vegetables, <0.08 to 0.15 (0.02 average); other vegetables, <0.08 to 0.40 (0.10 average); beverages and milk, <0.08 (the detection limit)(2). Benzo(e)pyrene levels of 0.05 to 23 ug/kg were detected in fat samples taken from 26 food products on the Finish market(3); the highest levels were in margarine(3). Benzo(e)pyrene concentrations of 1.29-89.94 ug/kg were detected in Spanish olive pomace oil(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: Lettuce and rye that were grown at a site near a highway had benzo(e)pyrene concentrations of 0.1 to 3.5 ug/kg fresh wt(1). Since the 1840s, crops have been harvested and stored for long term agricultural studies at a site in the UK(2); benzo(e)pyrene levels in grass samples were found to vary from 28 ug/kg in 1860 to 1862 to 93 ug/kg in 1879 to 1881 and then fall gradually to 5 ug/kg in 1985 to 1986(2); between 1877 and 1984, levels in wheat grain ranged from 0.29 to 2.50 ug/kg with the lowest levels occurring most recently(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: Oysters taken from Arkansas Bay and Galveston Bay in US waters contained benzo(e)pyrene levels of 0.2 to 2.1 ug/kg(1). Lobsters collected near Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia in 1982 and 1984 contained benzo(e)pyrene concentrations of 210 to 1400 ug/kg in the digestive gland and 10 45 ug/kg in the tail muscle(2). Analysis of various Nigerian freshwater fish found benzo(e)pyrene levels of 0.32 to 45.24 ng/g dry wt(3). Benzo(e)pyrene concentrations of 0.21-12 ng/g wet weight were detected in oysters collected from 18 stations in the Yatsushiro Sea, Japan in 2010(4). In cooked fish the amount of benzo(e)pyrene present depends on the method of cooking: time of exposure, distance of the heat source and whether or not the melted fat is allowed to drip into the heat source. In smoked fish and gas broiled fish, benzo(e)pyrene concentrations ranged from traces to 1.9 ug/kg and 1.2 ug/kg, respectively(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: Benzo(e)pyrene concentrations of 66-89 ng/g dry wt were detected in seston blue mussel (Mytilus edulis L.) taken from the coastal area of the northern Baltic(1). Gallbladders of common eider ducks (Somateria mollissima), which feed on the mussels, had a mean concentration of 2.1 ng/g dry wt(1). Benthic organisms (worms and midges) taken from the Raison River and Lake Erie near a Detroit power plant had benzo(e)pyrene levels of 20 to 110 ppb(2). Slugs, beetles, millipedes, earthworms and Casuarina littorina collected near a roadside in Brisbane, Australia contained 7, 2.5, 1, 13, and 4 ng/g wet weight benzo(e)pyrene, respectively(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: The following benzo(e)pyrene concentrations have been reported for cigarettes(1): mainstream cigarette smoke, 0.1 mg/kg smoke condensate; 0.5 ug/100 g burnt material; 1.3 ug/100 cigarettes; 2.5 ug/cigarette; 1.9 ug/1000 cigarettes; and 13.5 ug/cigarette in sidestream smoke(1). Concentrations of 1.8 ug/100 cigarettes was found in mainstream smoke of marijuana cigarettes(1). Concentrations of 0.23 to 48.9 mg/kg have been detected in fresh and used motor oils(1). Analysis of Alberta Sweet crude oil found a benzo(e)pyrene concentration of 5 ug/g(2). The benzo(e)pyrene concentration of several gasoline fuels ranged from 0.29 to 1.4 mg/L(3). The concentration of a high temperature coal was found to be 0.50% benzo(e)pyrene(4). Analysis of various new motor oils found benzo(e)pyrene concentrations of 0.03 to 0.402 ug/g while analysis of used motor oils found concentrations of 0.29 to 48.9 ug/g(5). Soot collected from open fire burning of various types of coal and wood had benzo(e)pyrene levels of 2 to 39 ppm(6). Average benzo(e)pyrene emissions for the burning of the following wood, ug/kg: almond, 17; walnut, 18; fir, 54; and pine, 24(7). Benzo(e)pyrene was detected at a level of 31.9 ppm in coal tar from the Sydney Steel Corporation's facility at Sydney, Nova Scotia(8). It was found in coal tar and carbon black at 6.1 mg/g and 190 ug/g(9). Emissions of benzo(e)pyrene from the burning of various types of coal have been reported as 0.02 to 10.3 mg/kg(1). Benzo(e)pyrene was detected in bituminous coal(10). Benzo(e)pyrene was detected in smoke particulates from 10 brands of cigarettes at levels of 3.0-12.4 ng/cigarette(11).

StringWithMarkup.String: Benzo(e)pyrene has been detected in commercial waxes with up to 0.039 mg/kg and 12 to 48 ug/kg present. 0 to 0.23 mg/kg benzo(e)pyrene was detected in petrolatum, 150 to 180 mg/kg in creosote and 1850 to 1880 mg/kg were reported in coal tar samples. A concentration to 52 mg/kg was found in petroleum asphalts and 5400 7000 mg/kg in coal tar pitches(1). Benzo(e)pyrene was identified in crankcase oil, fire soot and car soot at mean concentration of 0.46, 1.04, and 2.70 ug/g(2). The mean concentration of benzo(e)pyrene in used lubricating oils from gasoline, M15, diesel and gas fueled vehicles was 22, 110, 0.37, and 11 ppm, respectively(3). Benzo(e)pyrene was detected in crude oil from S. Louisiana, Kuwait, and Qatar at 2.5, 0.5, and 28.9 mg/kg, respectively(4). Benzo(e)pyrene was identified in soot extracts from a GTD 5 and a D 54A diesel engines(5). Benzo(e)pyrene emission rates from a noncatalyst automobile, a catalyst equipped automobile and a heavy duty diesel truck were 45.8, 2.0, and 2.6 ug/km, respectively(6). Benzo(e)pyrene concentrations in tire wear particles, brake lining particles, and road dust particles were 5.2, 0.84, and 2.7 ug/g of particle sample, respectively(7).

Section.Description: Potential way(s) in which people may come into contact with a hazardous chemical.  Examples of common exposure routes are inhalation, ingestion, skin/eye contact.

Reference: (1) Wallingford KM, Quehee SS; Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons: Mechanism, Methods, Metabolism. Cooke M, Dennis AJ. eds., Battelle Press (1985)

(2) IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Polynuclear Aromatic Hydrocarbons Part I Chem and Environ Data. Volume 32: 225 232 (1983). Available from, as of Nov 7, 2016: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php

StringWithMarkup.String: Occupational exposure to benzo(e)pyrene may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where benzo(e)pyrene is produced as a product of incomplete combustion. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to benzo(e)pyrene via inhalation of ambient air, inhalation of tobacco smoke, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing benzo(e)pyrene(SRC). Since benzo(e)pyrene is a product of incomplete combustion, occupational situations involving heating organic material may potentially result in exposure to this compound through inhalation of air particulate matter and dermal contact with combustion products(1). The general population will be exposed to benzo(e)pyrene through the smoking of tobacco, inhalation of polluted air and by ingestion of food and water contaminated by combustion effluents(2).

Reference: (1) Bjoerseth A et al; Scand J Work Environ Health 7: 223-32 (1981)
(2) Bjoerseth A, Lunde G; Amer Ind Hyg Assoc J 38: 224-8 (1977)
(3) Lesage J et al; Amer Ind Hyg Assoc j 48: 753-9 (1987)
(4) Heikkila PR et al; Scand J Work Environ Health 13: 431-7 (1987)
(5) Gressel MG et al; Appl Ind Hyg 3: 11-17 (1988)
(6) Khesina AY; Environ Health Perspect 4: 49-53 (1994)
(7) Petry T et al; Ann Occup Hyg 38: 741-52 (1994)
(8) Petry T et al; Ann Occup Hygiene 40: 345-57 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: A benzo(e)pyrene concentration of 1.45 ug/cu m was detected in workroom air inside a Norwegian aluminum manufacturing plant(1). Air monitoring in a Norwegian plant producing electrode pastes for use in electric smelting furnaces found upper limit benzo(e)pyrene concentrations of 0.8 ug/cu m(2). Average exposure to workers in aluminum refinery, silicon carbide and refractory brick industries was determined to be about 1 ug/cu m(3). The mean benzo(e)pyrene exposure to workers in a factory that impregnates wood with creosote was 0.03 ug/cu m(4). Emissions generated during the pouring, cooling, and shakeout of castings made with the evaporative pattern casting process contained benzo(e)pyrene at concentrations of 34 and 11 ug/kg for aluminum and iron castings, respectively(5). Benzo(e)pyrene was detected in the workplace air of a coke plant at a concentration of 1.0 ng/cu m(6). Stationary air samples collected near the ovens of two silicon carbide process plants contained benzo(e)pyrene concentrations ranging from 120 to 1219 ng/cu m in one plant and 279 to 313 ng/cu m in the second plant(7). Benzo(e)pyrene was detected in air samples (taken at breathing height using personal sampling pumps) collected in the furnace area of two silicon carbide process plants at concentrations (ng/cu m) ranging from (Plant A and B): 42 to 200 and 279 to 777 for the foreman; 18 to 104 and 266 to 1879 for the crane operator; 176 to 320 and 360 to 458 for oven workers whose tasks were in close proximity to the oven; and 1086 to 3844 and 385 to 632 for oven workers whose tasks did not involve direct work at the oven site(7). Benzo(e)pyrene was detected in air samples (taken at breathing height using personal sampling pumps) of 6 workers in a plant producing carbon anodes for aluminum electrolysis, worksite, concentration of benzo(e)pyrene (ug/cu m): forming section, 0.64 to 1.97; paste plant, 1.01 to 3.83; store section (broken green anodes and burned anodes), 0.13 to 0.55; forming section, 1.51 to 3.27; store section (coke) paste plant, 0.14 to 1.50; and all worksites, 0.22 to 3.34(8).

Section.Description: The average amount of the compound taken into the body through eating, drinking, or breathing.

Reference: (1) Dennis JM et al; Food Chem Toxicol 21: 569-74 (1983)
(2) Vaessen HAMG et al; Toxicol Environ Chem 16: 281-94 (1988)
(3) Matsumoto H, Kashimoto T; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 34: 17-23 (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: FOOD: Based upon a total diet study conducted in the United Kingdom, the total dietary load of benzo(e)pyrene is 0.17 ug/person/day assuming a total diet consumption of 1.46 kg food and beverages(1). Based upon a survey of Dutch foods, the mean intake of benzo(e)pyrene was reported to be 0.14 ug/person/day(2). AIR: Based upon an ambient air monitoring study conducted in Osaka, Japan in 1981-1982, the avg daily respiratory intake was determined to be 22 ng/day/man(3).

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
